commentBody:
For those who solve on a stone tablet, the druids (who also manage that English rock group) require the special squares be incised with an em dash, a forward slash, and a hyphen. Your solving platform/format may be more forgiving.



Gotta dash.
I don‚Äôt think I got any PBs this week, but I think this might be my PB for a consecutive week (starting Monday, ending today). 61:29!
So close to a PR, but I had the actual word rather than the punctuation works. Ah well.  A fun solve.

Today's prediction is that there are going to be lots of people expressing surprise, astonishment, wonder, annoyance, dislike, anger, hate, bewilderment, plus a whole lot of things that could be characters in "Inside Out," at the notion that you could have a punctuation mark occupy squares in a crossword puzzle.

Mostly, things like "they're called cross WORDS, not cross HYPHENS"...

Ack it‚Äôs sleeping cars (from 2023) all over again!

I would have appreciated having ‚ÄúLINE‚Äù being accepted. It‚Äôs annoying for these innovative puzzles to be bogged down by me wondering if the interface is going to accept what I think is correct, rather than accepting all permutations of ‚Äú-‚Äú, ‚ÄúL‚Äù, ‚ÄúL/-‚Äú, ‚Äú-/L‚Äù.

Other than that, I thought the puzzle was delightfully breezy. Congrats and thanks Harry!

For those with this weekend‚Äôs print magazine, Patrick Berry has his weekly word puzzle, this one entitled Product Re-Views.
Does anyone see an error sentence #8?
Based on previous puzzles feels like having the word or the symbols should have worked.

For me, the title was a dead giveaway to the theme. I‚Äôm not familiar with the term ‚Äúmulti-hyphenate" meaning a person with multiple talents, so that was something new I learned today.  

I first entered DottED LINE for the revealer, but that was quickly corrected and it was a smooth and enjoyable solve throughout. 

Nicely done, Harry. I can see why it took more than just a dash of effort to construct. I suspect you are a multi-hyphenate yourself.

The aha when I realized that hyphens went in the squares and that they worked in both directions, well, that brought on a mighty surge of adrena----.




Et tu, emu.

I got to do all hyphens at the end, all in a row. 

Fun and satisfying puzzle and ending!

Jamie MOYER had some baseball magic that wasn‚Äôt a blazing fastball or wicked curve. Just placement, pacing and smarts, I guess. It got to be pretty amazing to see him show up year after year after year.

For me a great Sunday. Relatively little help trouble which is unusual for me. Figured out the separated words early on and put in line instead of - so had to go back and fix that. But enjoyable puzzle
New Sunday best at 17:20. I knew almost immediately a letter was missing from a bunch of words. And the title was a little too obvious of an explanation
Replacing "DASH" with "----" and watching everything suddenly click felt like an outerbody experience.
I can't say I've ever been asked to "cut along the dashed line," dash it all!
I didn‚Äôt see the title and had LINE entered instead of dashes. Slightly frustrating. Fun puzzle altogether.
Fantastic puzzle! Well done, Harry!
I will, as usual, beg for NYT to keep these gimmicky puzzles to their day and definitely out of Sundays.
The columnist has missed the point of the UPARROWS solution, I think. They "make you jump" because pressing the up arrow in a game often causes the character to leap upwards.
Clever.

Fun puzzle! The title really helped to catch onto the concept, but I was looking for double hyphens for some reason. 

And my best Sunday time yet - under 29 minutes (28:59). I‚Äôd like to hear what times others have done - I have no idea if this is really short or just short for me. Honestly, I‚Äôm not a fast solver - I tend to plod along, but this one really flowed. 

(Streak is now at 744 games. Sorry for the bragging, but it‚Äôs been hard won - with three software glitches that wiped out my record (big thanks to the tech support team for restoring it!) and a 5-day hospital stay, I‚Äôm very pleased (and a bit surprised) I‚Äôve been able to maintain it.)

Thanks for reading - this community is a great break from the nonsense of the world. 

Happy New Year, everyone!
Very cute. Enjoyed a lot.
Lots of fun! Congrats, Harry Zheng!
Fun and interesting but too easy for Sunday. Do-rag was a stretch.
Fun puzzle!  Thank you
A great teaser of a crossword. Did have to use reveal word for some Americanisms eg brand names. On the whole I liked the idea of the dashes. More of those please.
Should have allowed ‚Äúline‚Äù, since, individually, those are hyphens, not dashed lines.

Such a fun, final Sunday puzzle for 2024. Thanks. 
 
 My favorite clue was Vanishing point.
I also have The Pink Panther theme song playing in my head
and I don't mind it.

Happy week to all and big hopes for the new year.

May our fears be unrealized and our good health, good
intentions - good everything - prevail.

Thanks to all in our special community.  You help more than 
you'll ever know. :)
This was an unusual puzzle in that it really made a difference to check the puzzle title first.

Ugh!  I so rarely finish the Sunday puzzle and have it stuck at ONLY putting the letters into the five odd answers instead of what was asked for drive me nuts! I went through the entire puzzle three times trying to find what might usually be a a single letter being off. Grrrrrr.

So many dashes and lines‚Ä¶.!

DASH WORKER:  Old Joe from the electric utility doesn‚Äôt have much use for the concept of safety first.

DASH CHARTS: the intern given the job of preparing the visual aids pulled an all-nighter and got the data mixed up.

DASH DRIVES:  What the batter does next.

DASH DANCES:  When the band gets up to 300 bpm.

DASH BACKER:  the player who thinks that confusing the other team has strategic value.

Oh this was a tough one -- not the solve; I did that fairly quickly for a Sunday -- but the automated checker which actually wanted dashes instead of the word LINE. I strongly believe that should have been counted as correct. But in any case... got it done!
I put hyphens in the boxes and it isn‚Äôt working. What am I supposed to do???

I finished about a half hour.  But, yet another puzzle that violates the most basic premises of a crossword puzzle.  
1 - answers are actually words
2 - where words cross, they need to be the SAME letter(s)

Are trh

Easy puzzle (finished 17:01 faster than my average), but performing 16 separate "... -> Rebus -> - -> Done" operations to put in the dashed lines (on an Android phone) was annoying. Not two-Sundays-ago annoying mind you (for nothing in the entire crossword universe could ever exceed that annoyance), but annoying nonetheless. But that aside, a pleasant Saturday-night diversion.

Solved the puzzle fairly quickly, only to spend another 15 minutes checking every cross before finally concluding that I needed to input LINE as hyphens. (Yes, I understand ‚ÄúDASHED LINE‚Äù as a revealer, but one could also argue you have to ‚ÄúDASH‚Äù the word LINE as an action of viewing in order to read the down answers‚Ä¶e.g. it isn‚Äôt clear to me that this mandates only one input type.)

One of my quicker solves (38 minutes) this week.  I figured the four letter word represented by the dashes after seeing the 28-across answer and the rest of the puzzle came together nicely.

Thank you Mr. Zheng for a fun Sunday solve!

Ha, the crossword gods smiled on me, for once. Unusually, I did this one on the laptop browser, rather than the phone app, so saw the title immediately. Started in the NW corner, looked at 1D, 2D, 3D and 4D, checked the key cross at 22A, and thought "Oh-ho, I know how this works!" Knowing I was looking for hyphens down and "----" across gave the puzzle so much structure that it felt pleasantly straightforward, which is a first for me. As an etymological aside ... For me, DO-RAG was the spelling I was taught by the first wearer I encountered, back in the mid '70s, who gave me the backstory that it was "a rag for his 'do". So that was a gimme, for me, though I was puzzled to read in the clue that it was a "variant". I've now read the NYT's "explanation" that "anyone who has ever worn a durag spells it durag", but I guess I ran into a counterexample in my formative years and never learned otherwise. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/14/style/durag-solange-met-gala.html
It is a dashing puzzle!!!
Crushed my best Sunday time, only 12 minutes and change. The theme came to me right away, and no clunky fill to slow me down. I enjoyed it but haters gonna hate.
Fire Harry Zheng

Two fun adjacencies I noticed. 
 In the upper left corner, UNDER is beneath ----- (LINE) and then over on the mid-east side, INTO intersects THIN AIR.  

And Caitlin has already posted a link to the SNL sketch featuring John Mulaney, among others, that I always want to post whenever there's a reference to the Cha Cha Slide.
Fun puzzle but LINE should have been accepted IMO

A Chorus - - - -
I Walk the - - - -
Whose - - - - is it Anyway?

Some of my favorite lines.
Done in a shade over 15 minutes. DASHEDLINE was late in my solve and kind of a letdown. I don‚Äôt think I ever heard or used that term in my life. Always used dotted line, even if they were dashes!

Not bad for a Sunday but I think that ‚ÄòLINE‚Äô should have been an acceptable option where the dashes went.

BTW As if the date of this puzzle, Lisa Blunt Rochester has not been sworn in. So she‚Äôs not a senator, she‚Äôs a senator-elect.

This one almost got me.  I spent a lot of time trying variations on L and H (for hyphen) and every character I could think of for the lines. I even got on a PC in case the mobile web site provided keyboard wasn't generating a proper dash.

In the end it was just that I didn't know enough about Viet Nam and had "most read" (as in a popular web article) instead of "must read".  Sigh.  Flyspecking is the last refuge of scoundrels, and me.

A medium difficulty puzzle, fine for Sunday.  It wasn't particularly notable, and the theme was very straightforward (maybe too much so) in the end.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Super annoyed that the only acceptable answer was putting an actual dash.
That was a good one. Lines took me a moment.
A very annoying puzzle to complete on my phone. For each dash I had to go to rebus, then hit the symbol key, then hit the dash.

Um, no. 

After being told for years to omit hyphens in crossword answers, now we're supposed to start including them?

I liked this puzzle! Why?
1) I love gimmicky puzzles!
2) As a Monday-Tuesday solver, I rarely solve Sunday puzzles without significant help.
3) I solved this one 5:28 faster than my average (with a few lookups, which I consider acceptable).
4) I found most of the cluing just the right amount of challenging for me.

About the dashes/hyphens: I figured out the trick pretty quickly after seeing the title. I actually had ‚ÄúI‚Äôs‚Äù instead of dashes because I was writing them vertically. üòÇ When I didn‚Äôt get the music, I changed them all to hyphens. No biggie. Lots of people have suggested that ‚ÄúLINE‚Äù should have been accepted. I disagree. Then the crossings would make no sense. 

Thank you Mr. Zheng for an enjoyable puzzle! üòä

Grr. It's things like this that make me grumpy. 

I do these puzzles on my phone (Android), so no title visible. And I've always done puzzles starting with 1A, then going through all the across clues before looking at any downs.

So I confidently fill in LINE this, and LINE that, and LINE the other, till I get down to 117A, where I started to be concerned about all those LINE answers. But, carry on.

I considered "dotted LINE", but chose "broken LINE", since it seemed obvious that the LINEs were breaking up the down answers.

After a while, it became clear from the crosses that it had to be DASHED LINE (even though that's not a common phrase), but I stuck to my guns till every square was filled in, only to be told _Not Quite_

Fly specked my way through it, only to decide that the powers that be want a dash (but what kind of dash? m-dash? n-dash?, hyphen? minus sign?) in those squares. 

So I laboriously go through all 20 of them, using 6 screen taps to replace each letter with a hyphen, for a total of 120 actions. All the while hoping - like _really_ hoping - that they didn't want both a dash and the letter, or a different kind of dash. 

After all that effort, I finally get the gold star. Yay, I guess? 

But it stopped being an enjoyable experience, and just became work the moment I realised that those five words had to be rebused. 

Bleh.

Not bad but took me a few minutes to figure out how to correctly enter the themed clues. Originally had [LINE][LINE][LINE][LINE]WORKERS, then tried just LINEWORKERS before finally just putting a dash to get the gold star.

Loved it :)

I thought the title was a give-away for the hyphens (I only realized the "line" quite late on), and don't really understand all the grumbling here about the construction.
definitely should accept LINE in the theme entries. good puzzle tho

Interesting theme, but it was too easy to spot.

The clueing was average, and the puzzle was fast too easy overall.

3/10

Thoroughly enjoyable.  I realized the words were split when I saw KAL-EL. (Which thoroughly impressed my spouse that I possess such knowledge.) 

Agree with comments about switching out line for a dash, but that does seem to fit with clever Thursdays. Otherwise, I BREEZED right on through.
Always love a puzzle with symbols! Simple theme that allowed for some really solid long answers and a breezy finish, nice job Mr. Zheng!

Extremely frustrating for the app to not accept ‚Äúline‚Äù in places of the dashes, given that there was not a clear clue to do so, and if you ‚Äúcut‚Äù the word ‚Äúline‚Äù out of each phrase it made just as much sense. 

Not to mention this puzzle following so quickly from the ‚Äúunchecked‚Äù clue debacle from a couple weeks ago made it doubly as frustrating. Especially because this was a fairly straightforward forward solve otherwise, yet I spent an inordinate amount of time searching for that one letter I didn‚Äôt have right.
thank you, harry zheng, for a perfectly fun sunday solve. i hope we don't have to wait a whole nother year for your next creation!
Congratulations to my fellow Hoosier Mr. Zheng on both the first Monday puzzle of the year and the last Sunday puzzle of the year. That's certainly a feat to brag about!

"Why aren't you dashing off to work on your punctuation?"
"Hyphen-ished already."

(These puns make their mark.)

I enjoyed working this and figured out the gimmick but was SO FRUSTRATED that it wouldn‚Äôt complete on my phone because I put in ‚Äúline‚Äù instead of dashes!  I thought you never use dashes in a xword! ‚òπÔ∏è
Could someone explain 117A please? I got ANTE from the crosses, which resulted in the happy music, but what it has to do with chips?

When I saw the puzzle title, I thought, ahh, we've got hyphens, and marched the first batch into the puzzle.  Definitely a big help in solving.  When I couldn't figure out why REUP wouldn't work? Oh ho, it's got a hyphen, so there will be three more with it, which made the puzzle almost a giveaway, but the rest of it was still fun to do and after an exhausting week I needed a little TLC.

Emily Dickinson is a lovely way to start a puzzle, especially with this one:

The Soul selects her own Society
Emily Dickinson

The Soul selects her own Society ‚Äî 
Then ‚Äî shuts the Door ‚Äî 
To her divine Majority ‚Äî 
Present no more ‚Äî 

Unmoved ‚Äî she notes the Chariots ‚Äî pausing ‚Äî 
At her low Gate ‚Äî 
Unmoved ‚Äî an Emperor be kneeling 
Upon her Mat ‚Äî 

I've known her ‚Äî from an ample nation ‚Äî 
Choose One ‚Äî 
Then ‚Äî close the Valves of her attention ‚Äî 
Like Stone ‚Äî 

Thank you, Harry Zheng.  It was worth all your trouble.
Breezy and clever.
If I had been solving a print edition, I would have considered the puzzle solved with the word LINE replacing the dashes. IMO, the app should have accepted LINE, DASH, dashes or spaces

Extremely frustrating that actually putting LINE in the answers, to complete the words, was incorrect. If it hadn't been for those, I'd have finished the puzzle without cheating. 

Thanks for ruining my golden streak on a gimmick.

Delighted to see Jamie MOYER in the puzzle. One of the pleasures of living in Seattle is the vast array of dedicated charitable organizations doing so much fantastic work. The Moyer Family is a treasure. https://elunanetwork.org/about/our-story/

The puzzle was really fun until I spent a full extra hour staring at my answers, checking my spelling, wondering where I went wrong only to find out that ‚Äúline‚Äù wasn‚Äôt accepted.

Idk in my opinion if the app accepts one letter for rebuses than it‚Äôs not intuitive that line wouldn‚Äôt be accepted here, particularly since it works in the across answers.
Crossing KAL-EL  with TAMIL, DEPP and ALOO is evil.

Fun puzzle! I basically filled all the downs first and left the acrosses blank, knowing some sort of trick were separating the words.

The revealer of DASHED LINE made everything click. Just lovely.

I also appreciate the rebuses working both ways.

If the puzzle is giving you a headache, here's a tip:

We discovered some years ago that a bag of frozen kernel corn makes a much better emergency ice-pack than a bag of frozen peas.  We always keep a bag in our freezer.  The corn stays frozen much, much longer!

We have a "family size" bag of corn, which we emptied into a larger Ziploc bag to make a flatter package. It's easier to form around a leg or an arm or a forehead, or any place that needs icing.
Enjoyed it, but super annoyed at mid-air/thinair in the grid :(

I, too, am mightily p.o.‚Äôed that my streak is now over because I got so frustrated trying to find my ‚Äúerror‚Äù (went back over the puzzle at least six times) that I just had to find out what it was:

ONE (1) square only! In (4)D, ‚Äúop-ed‚Äù apparently just had to have the hyphen included which meant that (22)A then read ‚ÄúLIN-WORKER‚Äù.

Now, I wouldn‚Äôt have minded so much if all the other across clues that included ‚ÄúLINE‚Äù also meant that their corresponding down clues ‚ÄúKAL-EL, MUST-READ, MID-AIR, ORE-IDA, RE-UP, AGE-OLD {Ok, not sure if age-old has a hyphen üòä}) had to have the hyphen included, but noooo ‚Ä¶ just ‚ÄúOP-ED‚Äù, apparently.

I included the word ‚ÄúLINE‚Ä¶‚Äù in all said across clues and that didn‚Äôt matter; it was just 4(D) which was an issue and now my streak is history. To paraphrase another contributor to this comment thread , I hate losing my streak because of a gimmick.

For anyone complaining that the word 'line' wasn't accepted, the name of the puzzle is 'multi-hyphenates'! The hyphen is staring us in the face from the beginning. Writing 'line' everywhere a hyphen should be would have conflicted with the theme and led to a less elegant puzzle.
Wasted a bunch of time trying to figure out what was wrong. Realizing finally I had to change the word line to the dashes. Grrrr

I figured out the trick when I entered ORE-IDA. Once that dash (hyphen) was in there, and I came to 112A, I immediately realized that the two places I had ‚Äúline‚Äù had to be replaced by dashes. If you entered ‚Äúline‚Äù, none of the down answers made any sense. Furthermore, the revealer basically tells us to put in the dashes in five locations. I guess I don‚Äôt understand why so many people are angry about this. If they read their down clues, they would realize that none of those answers were correct if the word line was there. 
Kudos to Harry on this clever Sunday puzzle. I really enjoyed it!

Not that this was a slam dunk, but I did catch on to the theme almost immediately. A clever device, one, as Harry mentions, that was none too easy to put into place. 
The puzzle took a while because there were a few clues that eluded me. (e.g. I don‚Äôt patronize Starbucks.) But I made steady progress and finished up nicely, with a smile on my face. Thanks, Harry, for a great one!
There‚Äôs not a rebus, but there is ARUBA.

Loved this one! A rare solve for me- Sunday in under 30 minutes. I was pleasantly surprised to get almost all the answers right away, and knew there were hyphens due to the title and KAL-EL, PRE-OP, OP-ED, and ORE-IDA (yum). Maybe I breezed through the clues because, as I now learn, the constructor is also fairly young? Or maybe a coincidence that sometimes knowledge just overlaps perfectly with the clues. Thanks for the fun ego boost, Harry!
Great puzzle. Once I figured out what the title meant it was easier to get the answers. Thanks for the challenge.

This was a fun puzzle and fast solve ‚Äî but an unfortunate day to be traveling and so have to do this on the phone rather than in the magazine as I do at home! In pen and ink I wouldn‚Äôt have had to guess (wrongly as it happened) at whether the app would accept LINE in the themers ‚Äî I would have gotten the trick, completed the puzzle my way, and contentedly gone about the rest of the morning. 

Not the end of the world, and I‚Äôve done enough of these to realize that might be the issue before I spent too much time flyspecking ‚Äî but I sympathize with those who get frustrated by the seeming arbitrariness of what gets accepted and what does not. 

But as I said ‚Äî fun puzzle nonetheless with a tight theme and a great aha moment when it came. Thanks Harry.
My best time ever for a Sunday! 30 mins! What a great way to start the day.
How do you enter dashes?

This was okay, but I ended up looking for non-existent errors because I entered LINE instead of ‚Äî‚Äî.  I remembered recently I had obsessed about how to enter the cutesy theme but it turned out I could have entered a rebus or either of the two letters or  a rebus with the two letters separated by a slash.  So this time I didn‚Äôt sweat it. Wrong.

I think the scoring software should have allowed "LINE" in lieu of "----" in the solution.

Once again, it's not a crossword issue, it's an emu problem.

Games.
No trouble withheld puzzle but never figured out how to add hyphens. Thought I‚Äôd find the answer here. Wrong.

A quick scan of the clues tells me that I am very not alone in trying to fit LINE instead of dashes in the blanks . . . EMUS IT'S NOT TOO LATE!!  Change the algorithm to accept LINE right now and you will get so many more happy solvers for the rest of the day.
Meanwhile, I thoroughly enjoyed the puzzle and am not burdened by streaks so I finally hit "reveal" to see those pesky little dashes.
Thank you Harry Z.

Inserting all those dashes using the clunky rebus interface was somewhat annoying - but it was quite clear that was exactly what I had to do once entering 'line' did not get me my gold star.

The puzzle itself was quite enjoyable - not too hard once I got the trivia out of the way by looking it up. Big name in pest control made me laugh - Ah, yes! Pest control! We all know all the really *big* brands in that market! Next week: big brand in manhole covers!

LINE should have been accepted. When the comments section reveals that dozens and dozens of commenting solvers went down the same path, the editors owe an apology - especially since rectifying it after solving is nothing but a pure annoyance. And one leading space in one rebus would send a solver into a frenzy of fruitless proofreading. It is the very definition of not fun. The title could have been interpreted either way.

I got robbed of a gold star because of incorrect formatting. First I just put "LINE" and left out the dashes. Then I took the time to enter rebuses
In each for L/- I/- N/- E/-   Still NO-GO. 

Boo.
Loved this.

For the life of me, I don't understand why anyone would enter L I N E instead of - - - -.  None of the down words work without the hyphen, and just look at the title of the puzzle.  MULTI HYPHENATES!!!  Good puzzle and lots of fun.

I've checked every single answer against the key 4 times. I have used the '-' key on my ipad to add the theme answers. And still the puzzle thinks it is incomplete.  I've even tried switching from my ipad to my iphone to my mac to re-enter the dashes.  But nothing has worked.  I'd prefer not to reveal the puzzle because it will interrupt my meaningless streak.  Is there something other than just keying in a regular dash/hyphen using the on screen keyboard that I need to do?  I liked the theme, but the execution is a bit lacking.

After finishing, I thought, "Well, that was an easy Sunday.  I guess there won't be many comments today."  

Then I was shocked to see 200 comments so early in the morning and more surprised that so many people wanted the word line in there.  It never occured to me to put anything other than dashes in the boxes right from the get-go (or is that get line go?).  Even if you started with line, the revealer tells you it's DASHED LINE.  

Oh well, fun idea, and I especially liked THIN AIR for [Vanishing point?].

A very gentle rebus. 

And a rabbit hole on Mustelidae. Googling an image of a wet badger really helps you see its similarity to the otter.
This was a very fun Sunday puzzle. Discovered the need for a dash four clues in, and this was my first where such a use was needed.

In the words of guitar virtuoso Randy California:  I got a line on you, babe!

Fun fact:  Randy got his last name from none other than ... Jimi Hendrix.

And, finally, you could do worse than to download Spirit's masterwork Twelve Dreams of Dr Sardonicus.

I'll stop now.  (You're welcome.)

I believe the true purpose of the NYT crossword puzzle is to teach the zen of hearing the happy music without actually hearing the happy music. I am at peace with having used "LINE" instead of hyphens, not getting my star, killing my streak but yet having heard the happy music beamed from another dimension. Om....

Just chiming in to agree that LINE should have been accepted in addition to ----. I‚Äôve read all the comments explaining why this is not a very smart thing to think, and I will save those commenters the trouble of replying to this by stipulating that they are smarter than me. But LINE should have worked.

On dasher, on dancer... Oh - and one appropriate answer history search today was for DASHEDHOPES. Yep - that was an answer in two puzzles. 

Where was I? Oh yeah - really intriguing puzzle - tough one for me, of course and had to cheat a bit in more than a couple of places, but managed to work it all out, until... of course -  what goes in those squares. Pondered and guessed and finally just went and looked at Xword Info to see what it was supposed to be. In retrospect I think that I really should have been able to figure that out. No big deal. 

Puzzle find today was a simply wonderful piece of construction. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

My last three posts went unpublished, and I have no idea why. One was merely an explanation to someone else's question about an entry. The others didn't have anything remotely controversial, and were long enough to evade the emus, if they're still around. We'll see how this one goes, especially since I'm usually the contrarian here.

I found this puzzle extremely easy, despite never having heard of many of the clues or answers, e.g. I Know a RHINO, Jamie MOYER, MOVES (I don't play chess), TRISH, and others. Got them all from the crosses. 

But the one that really got to me was the revealer, DASHED LINE, even though I got the first four dashes instantly, which made the rest of them a snap. I read the explanation and still don't like it. But that's on me. 

Perhaps because I solve on paper, I simply put those dashes in, and didn't have to worry about the formatting, hearing happy music, or breaking a streak, which I don't keep anyway. For a Sunday puzzle, I was completely underwhelmed and apparently in the minority, as usual.

Strands thread.  Please no spoilers until after the View All Replies button: 


Strands #301
‚ÄúFestival of Lights delights‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµ


Odd quirk with the allowed words list today.  No guest constructor.
Enjoyed this! Clever theme, not too cute or obtuse. New Sunday PB by quite a way.
CMON - You should APPROVE the word "LINE" and not only dashes!!!
What a great and clever puzzle. It took me a while to figure it out. I enjoyed it very much!

LINE should have been accepted.    We know the answer is dashed line, but given that the strikethrough option is unavailable on my phone's keyboard input as a formatting option,  regular LINE should Jane been accepted.
Put in dashes to begin with so I had no problem with that. Almost a record time.
I generally dislike rebuses (and who decided to call multiple letters in one square a "rebus" anyway?) and I really hated this one. Makes no sense to me. Ick.
Good puzzle. My mistake was thinking the Vietnamese name was "Pho," not Phu.  "Most-read" seemed just fine to me.
I enjoyed this puzzle and the theme, but the fact that a rebus, such as L/-, was accepted was poor form.

I‚Äôm a little surprised at the number of comments wishing for anything other than hyphens to be accepted. Maybe I just got ‚Äúlucky‚Äù today by reading the title right away and then having the ‚Äúaha‚Äù moment come so quickly in the NW corner. Not trying to toot my own horn (ok maybe I am but it‚Äôs such a rare moment), but wouldn‚Äôt letters of any variety make the down answers nonsense?

This was, to me, a wow puzzle build.  Four abutting hyphenated down answers whose across answers ALL read cleanly ‚Äì five times in the grid!  Huh?  What?  That is amazing!  Not only that, the six horizonal theme answers are symmetrical!  And nothing feels forced!

Deep bow to you, Harry, on that.

But even more important, how was the solve?  Just right for me today, as after the craziness of the holidays, I was looking for a comfort puzzle, and today, for me, it seemed like the editors were generous with footholds.  In addition, once I cracked the theme, the remaining theme answers and the sections they inhabited filled in without struggle.  Comfort indeed.

It is well known that people tend to remember, in various contexts, some sort of "Golden Age" that never existed. Like, how wonderful the '50s were and we should go back to those much better times. 

No, the '50s weren't all that great, if you view that era through a realistic lens. 

Likewise, all the whiners in here complain about how there was a "Golden Age" of wonderful puzzles when Will Shortz was the editor, and everything has gone to someplace very low in a hand basket since he's been on leave. 

No. The very same whiners who whine up a storm most Thursdays and Sundays -- any day when the puzzle is harder than a Monday or Tuesday, really -- were whining up a storm when Will was editing the puzzles, too. They just forget about all the whining that went on back then. 

There are no "Golden Ages." Stephen Jay Gould did a great job of debunking these sorts of false memories in Eight Little Piggies. 

Don't get me wrong -- I respect and admire Will Shortz and will welcome his return. I also respect and admire Joel Fagliano and all the effort he has put into these puzzles over the past several months. He doesn't deserve the vitriol that is directly or indirectly (passive-aggressively?) directed toward him when a puzzle is a little bit... puzzling.

Will's return will not result in less whining. There will be no return to a mythical "Golden Age" of whine-free puzzledom.

Having said that, it sounds like there is an issue entering dashes on mobile apps. That should be fixed.

Another technical failure. Fine puzzle but a waste of time figuring out the hoop to jump through for the solution to get digitally accepted.

One commenter, bemoaning the fact that the app wouldn't accept LINE... as an acceptable answer, noted that many paper solvers will happily put in LINE... and believe that they have solved the puzzle correctly.

I'm sure he's right, and my first, somewhat ungenerous, response was to think that every day someone makes an error, never knowing that they've made an error, but that doesn't make it any less an error.

But in the case of crossword puzzles, solvers have the opportunity to look in the paper the next day and find out whether they were right.

And it occurred to me that when one realizes that one has made an error in this way, the most common response wouldn't be, "Grrr.  How was I supposed to know that they wanted me to put in dashes???"  Rather, I suspect, most solver would say, "Oh, I didn't see that before. How clever!"

Paper solvers have the freedom of not being concerned with the time-clock or streaks (or the difficulty of having to click three times [gasp!] in order to type a dash).  They can just enjoy the experience of the solve as seems best to them.

And this reflection makes me wonder whether the on-line solve (and the semi-anonymous commentary) has made us all just a little bit worse as human beings.

Sunday record!

Early this morning around 5:00 a.m. PST, I realize I had my dates confused. Last night around 10:00 p.m. PST I completed today's Sunday 12/29 Crossword instead of Saturday's 12/28 crossword. I was tipped off when I saw the message "You've completed 20 Sunday crossword puzzles in a row" instead of the message "You're on a 140-day streak!" Dammit, I thought, I've blown my streak! Then, I completed yesterday's puzzle this morning, and, voil√†, to my surprise my streak was restored!

Who can clarify for me, perhaps an NYT games editor, what the rules, e.g. grace periods, are for completing puzzles on time and/or in order to maintain one's streak? I know I have lost my street in the past by failing to complete a puzzle. I know the Saturday and Sunday puzzles becomes available respectively at 10:00 p.m. EST and 6:00 p.m. EST the day before the published date. Does an individual puzzle need to be started and/or completed within some time relative to the release date and time?

@Jim 
I'm guessing it's for historical reasons. 

My first experience with rebuses was on the puzzle page in our local print paper, next to the local crossword. (Which, as I remember, was called a "crossword," not a "crossword puzzle"--but I could be wrong about that.) In those, images combined with letters to stand for words or syllables. Later, when beginning to solve NYT Sunday crossword puzzles in puzzle books, I discovered that some of them called for little drawings in the squares, such as a sun or an eye. I figured that out by looking at the answer key. When these puzzles first started appearing digitally, I was afraid that would be the death of the rebus. But I was intrigued to discover the NYT had come up with a solution: instead of entering a picture, there was a handy little rebus button where I could enter the word, which then got replaced with a picture upon successful completion of the puzzle. 

Now, any time that button is used, we tend to call it a rebus, even if only letters are entered.

Today, because the dashes represent "dashed lines", to my mind they are a rebus in the old sense even though in the desktop version the rebus button was not required.
